correction.p: This electronic text file was created by optical character recognition (OCR). OCR errors have not been corrected.
Illegible text in the original is indicated using unclear or gap, as appropriate. If corrected, the reference source is incidated with supplied.

normalization.p: Original spelling is preserved. When noticed, obvious misspellings are combined with the correct spelling as choice in the TEI. Ligatures are reproduced as multiple letters. Original footnote and marginal note sigla are replaced with sequential numbers for each entry.

punctuation.p: Extra space around punctuation marks is removed.

quotation.p: Quotation marks are retained as content in the text. Redundant open quotation marks at the start of lines inside block quotes are silently removed.

segmentation.p: The div type="entry" element divides the text into individual entries.
The div type="section" and div type="subsection" elements are reserved for entry subsections.

list.item: Encoding has been done using the recommendations for Level 3 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines.
Individual entries and page-breaks are encoded, but column breaks are omitted.
Running headers and side descriptions are not included.
Some font formatting is preserved: italic, small caps, strike through, subscript, superscript, underline. The following formatting is ignored: bold, font size, typeface.

projectDesc.p: All text was encoded for the Nineteenth-Century Knowledge Project to provide a machine-readable edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica to analyze.
Subject-level metadata was added to each entry using the HIVE automated vocabulary server created by the Metadata Research Center at Drexel University (https://hive2.cci.drexel.edu).

samplingDecl.p: This release reproduces the text matter for all entries. It does not include images, tables, formulae, front- or back-matter. It omits volume 1, which consists of "Dissertations" rather than entries.

prefixDef.p: URIs with the prefix fast: point to terms in the OCLC FAST (Faceted Application of Subject Terminology) subject heading schema derived from the Library of Congress Subject Headings (LCSH).
URIs with the prefix lcsh1910: point to subject terms in the volume Subject Headings Used in the Dictionary Catalogues of the Library of Congress, 7 vols., Library of Congress, 1910.
URIs with the prefix ht: point to page images in the Hathi Trust.
URIs with the prefix ia: point to page images in the Internet Archive.
URIs with the prefix nls: point to page images in the National Library of Scotland.

div.p: CASTRO, a city of Italy, in the Neapolitan province of Otranto. It is situated upon a hill on the Adriatic Sea, and contains 7789 inhabitants, who carry on extensive fisheries. The neighbourhood is celebrated for the growth of tobacco.

CastroGiovanni, a city of the intendancy of Calatanisetta, in the island of Sicily. It stands on the high mountain of Ena, in the centre of the island, in a healthy and moderately fertile district. In the neighbourhood are extensive salt mines, which furnish the vicinity with that commodity. It is a walled place, in which are the remains of the celebrated temple of Ceres and Proserpine. The inhabitants are about 11,000.

CastroMarim, a port in the province of Algarve, in the kingdom of Portugal. It is situated at the mouth of the Guadiana, the boundary betwixt Spain and Portugal, and is not more than two miles from Ayamonte, in Andalusia. This town contains 450 houses, and 1800 inhabitants, many of them employed in fishing and in a smuggling trade. Lat. 37. 11. N.

CastroNuovo, a city of Sicily, in the intendancy of Girgenti. It is a healthy spot, containing 4700 inhabitants, who cultivate cotton and grow excellent wine. Near to the city are some extensive marble quarries, which furnished that stone for the royal palace of Caserta.

CastroReale, a city of the intendancy of Messina, in the island of Sicily, situated on a triangular and rocky mountain, in a salubrious atmosphere, and on a soil highly productive of excellent wine and oil. It is 150 miles from Palermo, and contains about 11,000 inhabitants.
Castrodel Rio, a Spanish town in the province of Cordova, with 4600 inhabitants. Lat. 37. 48. N.

Castrode Urdiales, a sea-port of Spain, in that part of the province of Old Castile which is called Cantabrica. It is situated on the river Santona, and, if it were as well protected from the westerly winds as from every other, would be a most valuable port.

CastroVillari, a city of Italy, in the Neapolitan province of Calabria Citeriore, and situated on the river Cos-cile. It is well built, and contains 5600 inhabitants, who carry on a considerable trade in the products of the vicinity, viz. in wine, oil, cotton, mastic, manna, and fruits of various kinds.

CastroVireyna, a province of Peru, bounded on the north-west by the province of Cunete, on the north by that of Yauyoo, on the îrørth-east by that of Angiraes and by the jurisdiction of Huamanga and Huanta, on the west by that of Vilcas Huaman, on the south-west by that of Lucanas, and on the south-south-west and west by that of ĭca. From east to west it is sixty-six miles in length, and from north to south seventy-five miles in breadth. This province throughout is barren and uneven. Its productions are wheat, maize, and potatoes; and in some of the valleys where the cold is not severe, fruit is plentiful. Considerable numbers of Peruvian sheep are fed here, and their wool forms the principal article of traffic. The population amounts to about 7000. The capital of the province, which bears the same name, is an insignificant town, situated on a lofty mountain, and subjected to intense cold.
